audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker announcing that the video is sponsored by a product called "Paperlike." He describes Paperlike as a screen protector that makes writing or drawing on an iPad feel like paper, encouraging the audience to click the links in the description for more information. The speaker uses a professional and clear tone. There are no detectable ambient sounds or music throughout the clip.

The audio begins with a friendly, upbeat male voice introducing himself as "Karma Medic" and welcoming listeners to another "dose." He mentions being a third-year medical student and having gone paperless with his iPad Pro, noting its use for note-taking. The speaker describes receiving comments about his color-coding strategy when using the app Notability. He explains how the audience can use or build on his strategy based on his explanation. As the speaker concludes this segment, background music of an electronic style, having a mellow and optimistic mood, fades in.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing his preferred note-taking app on his iPad Pro, stating, "I use an app called Notability." He shares that he finds it the best note-taking app. He makes a remark about how his notes "look really messy," but can still read them. To prove his point, he rapidly reads a series of notes aloud. He then moves onto the topic of how he color-codes his notes.

The clip starts with one male speaker describing his note-taking system, including the structure of the page with title and three columns. The speaker states the system increases hierarchy and organization of the page and also helps with memorization based on the information's physical location. The speaker then describes how the pages are read, the first one having very solid colors. He explains he uses the second page that has more neutral colors, and custom pale colors as they are easier on the eyes during long studying sessions. The speaker then expresses interest in discussing specific colors and their meanings.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing his method of using a bright pink color to write the title of his lectures. He explains his organization system where lectures are numbered and correspond to specific topics within the same subject of his notes. He references a lecture titled "Lecture 03" which is on the subject of "HIV pathogenesis."

The audio begins with a male speaker detailing a note-taking method, describing how he writes "lecture headings or the subtitles" in a light blue color. He further elaborates on writing general information in light gray, clarifying its purpose as not being a title or something important. He mentions this would be the main pen he uses for most of his writing.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing the colors he uses in his lecture notes, mentioning a dark yellow-orangey color for subheadings and lists, and red for highlighting important information. The speaker's tone is informative and instructive. He mentions the ability to import and paste pictures, such as lecture slides, onto an iPad, which he then uses for further annotation. The speaker is then interrupted by a young girl, presumably his daughter, who enters the room. The male speaker greets her with a warm tone as she brings him some food. The clip ends with the male speaker ready to continue the video.

The clip features a single male speaker with a calm, informative tone, explaining the color-coding system used in his notes. "Dark purple" is used for information considered "high yield", likely to appear on tests, while "light purple" indicates information from past tests that must be memorized. He emphasizes the importance of light purple, stating "know this, know this, know this" before introducing the sponsor of the video, Paperlike.

A male speaker describes the Paperlike product, emphasizing that it makes writing on the iPad feel like paper, providing extra grip and protection. He says that using it has been a "natural transition from writing on paper to writing on an electronic device" and highlights how it helps protect the screen, even mentioning that it has "already saved me on more than one occasion." He talks excitedly about the product and its benefits. He concludes by saying that he will leave links to the product in the description. Finally, he transitions back to the video.

The clip begins with a single, presumably male speaker who highlights that the next color of importance to him is light green. He continues, speaking about how light green is only reserved for information related to drugs, treatment, or drug management, and how he can easily identify drug-related information when scrolling. He uses an example in a matter-of-fact tone: "first-line treatment is methotrexate," and then gives another example of the anti-TNF alpha therapy which are often prescribed. He notes that some may not be able to read what he wrote, but as long as he can, that is what is important. He finds this helpful, especially in exams when dealing with different names of drugs, noting how it can help him remember lecture notes. He summarizes that it is a helpful way for him to further categorize information, and that it works very well.

A single speaker, presumably male, discusses the color brown in note-taking, describing it as a marker for information deemed important enough to write down on a second review. The speaker's tone is informative and slightly analytical, emphasizing the color's significance in standing out among other colors.

The clip features a male speaker discussing highlighting techniques for note-taking using various colored highlighters. He mentions the aesthetic of color combinations and recommends using darker colors when necessary. He acknowledges a beeping sound, dismissing it, and asserts that highlighting is about personal preference and emphasizing important information. He concludes by stating that he has covered all colors he uses in his color-coding system in Notability while taking lecture notes at medical school.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker expressing hope that listeners enjoyed the video and learned something new. He encourages viewers to like the video and subscribe for more content, concluding with a sign-off and a promise to see them again at the same time and place, followed by a farewell. The audio clip ends abruptly.
